item.title: Iran-Israel War May Pause After Trump Says Ceasefire Reached
item.description: Iran and Israel may be nearing a pause in their 12-day war after President Donald Trump announced a ceasefire in a conflict that saw key Iranian military leaders and scientists eliminated, US bombing of Iranian nuclear sites and missiles launched at Israel and a US base in Qatar.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla, Fiona MacDonald, Catherine Lucey, Kate Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Smoke rises from a location allegedly IRGC's Sarallah Headquarters in north of Tehran after being targeted by Israel on June 23. Photographer: ELYAS/AFP

item.title: Japan’s Akazawa Says Still Working on Date for Next Trade Talks
item.description: Japan and the US are still working on setting the timing for the next round of cabinet-level trade talks, Japan’s point person for the negotiations said, as the deadline for a deal to avert another hike in tariffs nears.
item.dc:creator: Brian Fowler

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa

item.title: Iran-Israel War Heads Toward Pause After Trump Claims Ceasefire
item.description: Iran and Israel appeared to be nearing a pause in their 12-day war after President Donald Trump announced a surprise ceasefire in a conflict that saw key Iranian military leaders and scientists killed, US bombing of Iranian nuclear sites and a salvo of missiles launched at Qatar.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Kate Sullivan, Fiona MacDonald, Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: (Photo by ELYAS/Middle East Images/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Kospi Surges to Lead Stock Gains in Asia After Mideast Ceasefire
item.description: Asia’s stock benchmark climbed the most in seven weeks, led by technology shares, as risk sentiment improved after US President Donald Trump announced a tentative ceasefire between Israel and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Winnie Hsu

media:content.media:description: A screen displays the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) and the exchange rate between the South Korean won and US dollar inside a trading room at Hana Bank in Seoul, South Korea.

item.title: YouTube Exemption From Australian Teen Social Media Ban Opposed by Regulator
item.description: Australia’s online regulator called on the government to reverse its controversial exemption for YouTube from a social media ban for under-16s, an unusual intervention that echoes similar pleas from rival platforms including Facebook and TikTok.
item.dc:creator: Angus Whitley

media:content.media:description: Photo by JOSH EDELSON/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: JOSH EDELSON/AFP

item.title: Thailand Targets Cambodian Scam Centers Amid Border Dispute
item.description: Thailand announced a raft of security and trade measures to cripple transnational crime syndicates in Cambodia, as Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra seeks an upper hand in a simmering border dispute with its neighbor.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Cambodian people waiting to enter Thailand line up at the International Border Checkpoint of Poipet, Banteay Meanchey province, Cambodia, June 8, 2025. Thai Foreign Ministry spokesperson Nikorndej Balankura said on Monday that since Cambodia has shortened the permitted stay for Thai nationals to seven days, Thailand has also adjusted its policy accordingly, setting the limit of Cambodian nationals' stay in Thailand to seven days. Touch Sokhak, deputy spokesperson for Cambodia's Ministry of Interior, said on the same day that in response to Thailand's cut of the visa-stay period for Cambodian citizens, Cambodia has shortened the permitted stay for Thai citizens from 60 days to seven days. (Photo by Meanchey/Xinhua via Getty Images)

item.title: Harvard Wins Longer Block on Trump’s Foreign Student Ban
item.description: A federal judge issued another court order letting Harvard University keep hosting foreign students, this one in its fight to overturn President Donald Trump’s proclamation barring their entry to the US.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos

item.title: UK Urges Iran to Grasp Opportunity to Return to Talks
item.description: The UK has urged Iran to de-escalate and return to talks with the international community following the announcement of a ceasefire in its conflict with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Alex Morales, Fran Wang

media:content.media:description: Peter Kyle

item.title: Korean Consumer Confidence Jumps to 4-Year High on Stimulus Hope
item.description: South Korea’s consumer confidence rose to the highest in four years as easing domestic political uncertainty, fresh fiscal stimulus and hopes for pro-growth policies under the new administration buoyed sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee

item.title: Senate GOP to Offer $40,000 SALT Cap With Lower Income Threshold
item.description: Senate Republicans are coming around to the $40,000 cap on state and local tax deduction key House lawmakers demand in President Donald Trump’s massive tax package, but they want to lower the income threshold.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Steven T. Dennis

item.title: Key Senator Calls to Delay Meeting of New RFK Jr. Vaccine Panel
item.description: Republican Senator Bill Cassidy is seeking to delay a scheduled meeting of vaccine advisers selected by Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. out of concern they’re not sufficiently qualified.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Cohrs Zhang

media:content.media:description: Bill Cassidy Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: Putin Going to War With NATO Would Cost World $1.5 Trillion
item.description: The NATO chief says Russia may be ready for an attack on eastern Europe within five years. Bloomberg Economics ran the numbers on what that would mean.
item.dc:creator: Alex Kokcharov, Jennifer Welch, Alberto Nardelli, Julia Janicki, Tom Fevrier, Alex Newman, Tom Orlik, Ben Sills

media:content.media:description: Soldiers of the German 45th Armoured Brigade at a ceremonial roll-call in Vilnius, on May 22. Germany is in the process of deploying a 5,000-strong brigade to Lithuania on a permanent basis. Photographer: Paulius Peleckis/Getty Images Europe

item.title: UK Welcomes £40 Billion Amazon Investment Plan in Warehouses
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer welcomed a three-year program by Amazon.com Inc. to invest £40 billion ($54 billion) in the British economy over the next three years, including opening four new warehouses.
item.dc:creator: Freya Jones

item.title: Trump Thanks Iran After Attack Choreographed to De-Escalate
item.description: The Qataris knew the missile barrage was coming. So did the Americans. The Iranians had told them.
item.dc:creator: Peter Martin, Donato Paolo Mancini

item.title: Supreme Court Backs Trump on Deportations With Short Notice
item.description: A sharply divided US Supreme Court let the Trump administration resume quickly deporting migrants to countries other than their own, lifting a judge’s order that gave people 10 days notice and a chance to argue they would be at risk of torture.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC.

item.title: Gulf States Reopen Airspace and Resume Flight Operations
item.description: Several Persian Gulf states, including Qatar and the United Arab Emirates, have reopened their airspace and resumed operations at some of the world’s busiest airports after halting flights as Iran launched air strikes at a US base in Qatar.
item.dc:creator: Leen Al-Rashdan

media:content.media:description: FILE - Passengers walk at Hamad International Airport in Doha, Qatar, Nov. 10, 2022. (AP Photo/Hassan Ammar, File)

item.title: UK Vows to Spend 5% of GDP on Security by 2035 to Hit NATO Goal
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer will vow to spend 5% of British economic output on security by 2035, embracing an ambitious NATO target sought by President Donald Trump without providing a path on how to get there.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer.

item.title: Gauging the Fallout From the US Strikes on Iran
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Every Monday, Bloomberg Intelligence senior analyst Nathan Dean gives his insights into what’s been happening and what’s coming up in the nooks and crannies of government and markets. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Nathan R Dean

item.title: EU and Canada Sign Security Pact as Carney Pivots From US
item.description: The European Union and Canada have signed a security partnership that moves them closer to cooperation on military purchases, as Prime Minister Mark Carney aims to reduce his country’s dependence on the US for defense.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Seal

media:content.media:description: A member of protocol adjusts the EU and Canadian flags prior to an EU-Canada summit at the European Council building in Brussels, Sunday, Oct. 30, 2016. Canadian and EU officials, in a one-day summit, are to sign the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA). (AP Photo/Olivier Matthys) Photographer: Olivier Matthys/AP Photo

item.title: FTC Clears Omnicom Deal After Barring Advertising Boycotts Over Politics
item.description: Omnicom Group Inc., the third-largest US advertising agency, agreed to stop withholding online ads for political reasons to clear the way for federal antitrust regulators to approve the company’s $13.5 billion buyout of rival Interpublic Group.
item.dc:creator: Jef Feeley

media:content.media:description: The Federal Trade Commission headquarters in Washington, DC.

item.title: NYC Mayoral Race Tightens as New Poll Shows Mamdani Primary Win
item.description: The outcome of the race could help define the path forward for the Democratic Party.
item.dc:creator: Nacha Cattan, Arvelisse Bonilla Ramos

media:content.media:description: Justin Valdes Photographer: Arvelisse Bonilla Ramos/Bloomberg

item.title: A Weakened Iran Can Still Inflict Pain on the US — and the World
item.description: When the dust settled on Iran’s nuclear sites on Sunday after a US bombing raid that President Donald Trump said had “totally obliterated” its atomic program, one thing was still missing: its highly enriched uranium, which international authorities haven't seen for more than a week.
item.dc:creator: Golnar Motevalli

media:content.media:description: Portraits of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and late leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, as demonstrators protest US strikes on Iran's nuclear facilities, in downtown Tehran on June 22.

item.title: House Bans WhatsApp From Staffers’ Government-Issued Devices
item.description: Meta’s WhatsApp messaging platform has been added to a list of apps banned from government-issued devices for congressional staffers in the US House of Representatives, a move driven by concerns about the app’s data security.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Wagner

media:content.media:description: The Facebook Inc. WhatsApp logo on a smartphone arranged in the Brooklyn Borough of New York, U.S., on Tuesday, Oct. 5, 2021. Signal and Telegram, two private messenger apps, saw downloads and user sign-ups soar during the extended downtime of Facebook Inc.’s network of apps and services.

item.title: Satellite Images Suggest US Avoided Iran’s Nuclear Reactors
item.description: Pictures show the destruction at the Isfahan facility doesn’t include the buildings likely housing three research reactors.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

media:content.media:description: A satellite image showing destroyed buildings at the Isfahan nuclear technology center after recent airstrikes.

item.title: Harvard Alumni Group Urges School Not to Cave to Trump's Demands
item.description: A group of Harvard University alumni urged the school not to cave to the Trump administration’s demands as it restarts talks with the White House.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ryan

media:content.media:description: Banners hang from the Harry Elkins Widener Memorial Library on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US, on Tuesday, May 27, 2025. President Donald Trump on Monday threatened to divert billions in grant dollars away from Harvard University and give those funds to trade schools across the US, escalating his clash with the elite institution.

item.title: Noboa Grapples With Another High-Profile Prison Break in Ecuador
item.description: Ecuador’s government offered a $1 million reward on Monday for information leading to the recapture of suspected drug lord Rolando Federico Gomez after he escaped from a Guayaquil penitentiary disguised in a military uniform to pass checkpoints unhindered.
item.dc:creator: Stephan Kueffner

media:content.media:description: A military tank guards the Penitenciaria del Litoral in Guayaquil, Ecuador, on April 9. Photographer: Marcos Pin/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Ford Escalates Battery Job Warnings as Congress Mulls EV Cuts
item.description: Ford Motor Co. intensified its campaign to preserve clean energy manufacturing subsidies Monday, warning jobs at its electric-vehicle battery plant in southwestern Michigan could be at risk if Republicans in Congress pare back tax credits in President Donald Trump’s multi-trillion dollar economic package.
item.dc:creator: Gabrielle Coppola

media:content.media:description: The trunk of a Ford F-150 Lightning electric vehicle during the 2022 North American International Auto Show (NAIAS) in Detroit, Michigan, US, on Wednesday, Sept. 14, 2022. The Detroit auto show returns this week after a three-year absence and in a downsized format, reflecting a broader shift by car companies in how they reach consumers. Photographer: Emily Elconin/Bloomberg

item.title: France, Norway Say US, Israel Military Strikes on Iran Lack Legal Basis
item.description: France and Norway together questioned the legality of military strikes on Iran by Israel and the US, breaking with allies who have endorsed the attacks.
item.dc:creator: Samy Adghirni, Ott Ummelas

media:content.media:description: Smoke rises after a reported Israeli strike on a building used by Islamic Republic of Iran News Network in Tehran, on June 16.

item.title: Spain and Rutte Locked in a Showdown on Eve of NATO Summit
item.description: By refusing to agree spending increases to appease US President Donald Trump, Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez threatens to derail a NATO summit that Secretary General Mark Rutte needs to run smoothly for the sake of the military alliance’s future survival.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano

media:content.media:description: Sanchez in Albania last month.

item.title: Poland, Baltic States Seek EU Help to Reinforce Eastern Borders
item.description: Leaders from Poland and the three Baltic nations have called on the European Union to step up financial support for plans to reinforce their borders, the first line of defense on the bloc’s eastern flank.
item.dc:creator: Milda Seputyte

media:content.media:description: A Polish armored vehicle beside anti-tank defences at the first built part of the East Shield at Poland's border with Russia, in Dabrowka, Poland, on Saturday, Nov. 30, 2024. The National Deterrence and Defense Program East Shield is a comprehensive government program aimed at strengthening Poland's defense system, with a value of about 10 billion PLN to be implemented in 2024-2028.
